fields.text: How do you get to Carnegie Hall?  Practice, practice, practice!  The surest way to fail at anything is to simply refuse to try.  What if you try and try and try and try, and still you fail?  Well, did you at least have fun trying? But what if everyone in the world thinks you're a loser and a joke?  Um, I hate to tell you this, but most people in the world will never think of you at all.  They're too busy living their own lives.  Why aren't you?Some of us don't have any audience for our websites, you know, while others don't have a website at all.  Yet somehow we still manage to be happy.What do you have to be happy about today?  Have you got a hangnail?  If not, then count that among your blessings.  Did you have to eat anybody today?  If not, then add that to the list.  Did anyone chew you out today?  If so, then just be glad they didn't swallow.  If they swallowed, then I'm sure things will come out alright in the end...What if you leave Purdue and find out Purdue was never the problem?  Remember--things can always be worse.  You could be in Fortville right now.

fields.name: Lord Ontario
fields.text:
I haven't invested a dime in video games for years (with the exception of KOTOR which is pretty awesome if you ignore the occasional, if not massive, visual errors it tends to get). I'd still rather play old RPGs on my PS1 than damn near anything that's out these days. I did have a short term addiction to Prince of Persia: The Warrior Within, but having beaten that in about 12 game hours there isn't much more to do with it.



11. Develop the story, develop the characters



Gameplay is important I'll grant you, but I've always played games (particularly RPGs, but even games like Grand Theft Auto) for the stories and the characters. A game is much more fulfilling if you've spent 40+ hours guiding the path of characters that you've become attached to on an emotional level. There aren't enough games out these days that try to deliver an original storyline with engaging characters. Even SquareEnix has been dropping the ball lately. I guess gaming companies haven't noticed that games like FF7 are still among the best sellers of all time.



12. Replayability



What good is a game that I can beat in a few days and never want to play again? Ubisoft doesn't care because I've already paid them (not really, but you get my point), but something makes me believe that they should. Give me good gameplay, a solid storyline, dynamic characters, and a game that I can play for 40+ hours and I'm set. It's even better if I can play that game again. Take a lesson from Square: make the plot so ridiculously complicated that you have to play through it 4 or 5 times before you even know what the hell is going on.



13. Graphics aren't worth shit if the game sucks



Believe it or not few people will buy a game just for the graphics. If the game isn't worth playing no amount of bump mapping is going to save it.



BUMP!!!

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
Excellent additions, my Lord.I'll just add another one that I forgot:

14.  Let me quicksave, or count me out.

I'm just sick of games being ruined by the inability to quicksave.  Far Cry, Call of Duty 2, XIII, and Path of Neo are all based on autosave checkpoints.  Autosaves are fine for RPG's where you are less likely to have to fight a huge monster every single time you enter a new room, but action games absolutely require the ability to save the game anywhere.  Whithout it, when you get to a hard part, you have to replay the sequence leading up to it over and over and over until you finally beat the hard part.  In Far Cry, I was just so sick of replaying easy parts hundreds of times, I eventually just stopped playing it.



Let me save it wherever I want.  There is no reason not to.

fields.name: Peach Faygo Lover
fields.text: I think that video games are in the eye of the beholder. Sometimes you just like a game and you are not sure why. Example: Diablo is an awesome game, lots of gamers everywhere love to play it over and over again, but all those games taht come out that are just like Diablo but a different format, everyone hates. I mean the game is exactly the same its just a different storyline, yet no one likes them. Now yes, copying other games is a good way to get your game not played, but because Diablo was a first of its kind, everyone loved it and play it all the time. Now I like Path of Neo, keyword there is liked. The game had lots of bugs and the gameplay was pretty bad, also the gun fighting was not to my satisfaction. But when I installed the game the only thing I was really looking for was some descent hand to hand combat and it following the movie fairly well. I got that and so I was happy enough to get past the bugs and gameplay(which by the way the combat is really not that bad once you get used to it). Also it was kinda worth it to play the scene where you fight all the Smiths, and the surprise ending was neat. One last thing I'd like to say. Gameplay completly dwarves graphics, yet graphics enhance gameplay. If you have a solid storyline and gameplay, then you got a good game hands down, even if its text based. That is a thing that I would think developers would get from testing in alpha and beta.

fields.name: Barry
fields.text: To Shauvon,I understand that you disapprove of our weekend activities.  Given the smell of the room last night, I can hardly argue.  But I think Chris raises a point in that you previously took a proactive stance when alcohol was involved, and had a good time with us, anyway.  I don't know why you chose to keep to yourself the other night, but I'm sure that if you go back to trying to trying to enjoy yourself around us you won't have so many bad nights.What I don't understand is why you didn't say anything immediately when you had a problem.  You didn't suggest we find another place, you didn't tell us to stop for the night, and you definitely didn't let Mike know that he had to clean up.  You left the room and posted on your website that there was a problem, but you didn't tell any of us to our faces.  We (you, me, and Mike) need to sit down and talk about this instead of talking through your website.  Let's cut the passive-agressive bullshit and just talk to eachother.

fields.name: Barry
fields.text:
To Aili,

You weren't there.  All you have is hearsay.  I understand that you are trying your best to advise Shauvon.  Given what you heard, you made the best decision you could.  I'll give you some more background, and you can tell me if your impression of the night changes any.  We don't drink that often.  Speaking for myself, I have been drunk 4 times in my life.

We were not using Shauvon for his room.  You might not realize this, but three people live in this room.  Two of them were drinking.

Chris doesn't normally give Shauvon crap about drinking at all.  What he meant (and couldn't say properly due to being drunk) is that if each weekend is worse exclusively because you don't drink, then you should look at the cause of each weekend being worse.

We don't drink because it's cool, we don't drink because that's the only way we can feel good, we don't drink alone, and we don't drink in the morning or dring the day.  We drink because it helps us loosen up after a long week.  It's how we stay balanced.  All work and no play, after all.  In other words, we're happy drunks.

We don't expect Shauvon to be designated puker-turner.  We don't expect him to do anything for or with us.  He's welcome to join us, he's welcome to drink with us, stay sober in our company, videotape us, or just be elsewhere.  Besides, he has never acted as designated puker-turner, so why should we expect it?  Shauvon just left when the room smelled bad.  I was the one who woke Mike and got him to clean up.

We expect only one thing from Shauvon: tell us when we're doing something he won't tolerate.  You might not realize this, but he never told us 'guys, you're too loud' or 'guys, the room smells bad' or 'guys, can you do this somewhere else?'  We can go to Chris's room if necessary.  We could have done so last night, but the idea was never suggested.

fields.name: Shauvon's Mom
fields.text: Gentlemen, your excuses and self defenses may make perfect sense to you, but the fact is, I've heard them all before.  I had to watch my father drink himself to death and then I got to watch my brother drink himself to death as well.  It wasn't pretty.And Shauvon got to watch me watch these things.It's not his responsibility to tell you when your drinking bothers him.  It's your responsibility not to bother other people and to be in charge of your faculties enough to know when you're doing so.  Sounds to me as if you're doing a nifty little transference maneuver so that instead of looking at what you guys did to yourselves last night, you're now looking at what Shauvon has done as if he is somehow at fault.  Why are you making your behavior someone else's problem?  Talking is a good idea, guys, but it only works if you are willing to spend at least half the time listening.

fields.name: Notes from Alcoholics Anonymous
fields.text: Classic alcoholic lines:1.  I don't drink that much.2.  I didn't mean for that to happen last night.3.  It'll never happen again.4.  It wasn't my fault.5.  You should've stopped me.6.  I don't have a problem.  You're the one with the problem.7.  A little alcohol is good for you.8.  I just need it to unwind.9.  Everybody does it.10.  I can quit any time I want to.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
I just want to say that I originally created this post because I was at a party after the Crazy Monkey's show, and it was extremely lame because there were a bunch of stupid drunk people there.  I made it before everyone came back to the room to drink.



I don't want any more alcohol in my room, period.  I don't like what it does to people, and I don't want to enable my friends anymore.  All of it needs to go, and everyone needs to find a different place to 'relax'.  We'll just leave it at that.



I don't care if my friends are alcoholics or not.  I've seen what it does to someone, and I wouldn't wish that on anyone.

fields.name: chris
fields.text:
to shauvon:

What makes you thing we are alcoholics?  You of all people should know the only time we EVER drink is on a weekend, and that is not an every weekend event.  I get to tired from drinking to want to do it all weekend, I would get tired of drinking every day.  If you had not wanted us to drink their you should have told us before we started.  If you had we would have respected your choice and found another plce to 'relax' as you put it.  I'm not sure what changed to make you fell that way but I wish you would have told us.

You may not know this but, I lived were kids started drinking lots of alcohol at young ages.  You don't have to lecture me on what it can do to people.  

I must apologize for the 'drink then' then comment.  It should have contained more words then 'just drink'.  The way it should have gone was 'If you are not haveing in a given situation change it.'  I posted 'just drink' because I took your unhppiness with the situtation was becasue you did not drink.  It was meant as joke, and not serious comment.  That is why I have never seriously said you should drink alcohol.

fields.name: chris
fields.text:
to shauvon's mom:

I never made an excuse for drinking.  It is something I do every once and a while, Not every day.  I think it is a show of disrespect by jumping to the conculsion that I am an alcoholics with out knwoing anything about me.  Anything you know about me has come from what others think of me, and not what you know about me.

1 I did have to much to drink. 2) I didn't mean for Mike to get sick, but I didn't force him to drink. 3) It will happen again, but not in Shauvon's room.  4) It was not my fault for mike getting sick. 5) I am the onlyone that can stop me. 6) My drink less than 10 times in one year is a sign i dont have a problem. 7) Alcohol is sometimes good. 8) I don't use alcohol to unwind. 9) Not everyone does it. 10) I could stop drinking.

fields.name: Barry
fields.text:
What burns me about Friday night is that Shauvon went from silent acceptance to going straight to the RA if there was a problem.  I would have gladly listened to Shauivon's concerns, had he voiced them.  I would have even spoken for him if he didn't want to address our group alone.  This whole situation could have been averted.



I'm not saying that we should be allowed to drink in the room.  One of the points that Shauvon missed (and should have used) is that he is equally guilty as the rest of us if we are caught with alcohol in the room, unless he's the one turning us in.

I'm not saying that Shauvon's concerns about inebriation are without merit.  Alcoholism is a real problem for many people, and Shauvon had to watch others dear to him suffer because of that problem.

I'm not saying that Shauvon is responsible for our actions.  What kind of lunacy is that?  He wasn't even there.  How could he be responsible?  No one is responsible for the entire group.  Each person is responsible for his own actions.  At the same time, don't blame the group for the actions of an induvidual.  I'm just glad that Mike didn't choke and we didn't have to call an ambulance.



I rarely drink, and when I do, I watch how much I have.  I had my 'way too much' time last Fall, and I vowed not to repeat that episode because it was embarassing for me and disgusting and oppressive for everyone else.  I know my limits, and I don't push it.  I can even enjoy myself without alcohol, but I like to occasionally get 'buzzed' for a few hours.  Everything in moderation.



Enough of this.  I've been over this before.  Let's stop ranting on the website and sit down to discuss this like adults.  I find it immature that we can't face each other and say what needs to be said.  I suppose I'm no better, since I'm posting here, too.  This will be my last.  If any of you want to discuss this further, you know where to find me.

fields.name: Aili
fields.text: I'm glad to see that this situation has inspired such dialogue.  To the fray, I would add:1).  Anyone who has known Shauvon for two years and is really suprised to hear that he is uncomfortable with the people around him getting drunk has not made much of an effort to really get to know him.2).  Many, many, many, many people of all ages have not been drunk 10 times in their entire lifetimes.  But it's clear that I shouldn't pick on Chris anymore.  He clearly has enough problems without me adding to them.3).  It's true that I don't know you boys well, but the fact is, I don't have to know you to appraise the situation.  The fact is, I only have to know one thing:  each of you are willing to break the law/campus rules to please yourselves.  It is illegal for anyone under the age of 21 to consume alcohol.  Period.  Many people make it to the age of 21 without breaking that law.  I don't know why so many people can't, but frankly, I don't care.  If you think the law is unjust, you should work to change it, not blantantly break it.  What is more, it is clearly stated that drinking is not permitted in the dorms at Purdue, no matter what your age might be.  If you don't wish to abide by that rule, you should not live in the dorms.  It doesn't matter if Shauvon condones it or not.  Those are the rules you agreed to live by.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
I thought I would just say one more thing, just because that will punch it up to 19 comments.  19 is my lucky number.



It's ironic that I always wanted a post that sparked a lot of comments.  I guess I finally got it.

fields.name: Mike
fields.text: How unlucky :P

fields.name: Missy
fields.text: He's working on 3d studio max!

fields.name: Observer
fields.text: It's been interesting to follow these postings, because the issues you're discussing are things everyone should think about once in a while, and people need to share their thoughts to find out what other people are thinking, especially about such important issues.  Otherwise it's too easy to curl up in your own head, think you are always right about everything, and refuse to even consider anyone else's point of view.  How can you grow if you never consider anyone else's point of view?  All you can do is be a baby your whole life, sticking your tongue out at anyone who doesn't agree with everything you say.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: What's your point?

fields.name: Peter
fields.text: After reading these what strikes me the most is that nobody who was resposible for this whole debacle has even apologized. To the drinkers on here: When was the last time you drank without getting completely hammmered? Can you have a good time with just one or two drinks? (or even better, no drinks at all?) It is worthwhile to try it sometime just to see if you have your shit together. Shauvon, if the people on your floor are being this immature again, give me a call so you don't have to put up with that crap, we'll find something better to do. You can sleep on my couch instead of near a puddle of vomit.

fields.name: Mike
fields.text:
Oh yeah just for the record, I'm sorry about what happened a couple of nights ago (if you weren't there when I directly told Shauvon), and just to be safe, I also want to make sure you know that tonight I ate at windsor dining hall and had 2 spicy chicken sandwitches with a plate of fries.  The fries had ridges and I ate them with ketchup.  I had a couple of things to drink.  The first one was filled 3/4 of the way with coca-cola (I would of had cherry coke but they were out) and the other was orange.  I bet you can tell me what I ate first and how long it took to finish...



Point being...these blogs are hardly a good source of information and it wouldn't be too good of an assumption to think otherwise.  If you don't think I feel bad about the situation then you're dead wrong.  If you believe I didn't learn from my mistakes you're also wrong.  End of discussion.

fields.name: Andrew Monkey
fields.text: We all really appreciate the gift baskets you gave us before auditions.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: Wrong!!  It's an easy mistake to make, but he's not working in 3d Studio Max.  Better luck next time.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: Oh . . . I actually sent those out when I was sure that you had rejected me.  You probably shouldn't eat the muffins . . .

fields.name: somebody
fields.text: This would make a great song.

fields.name: somebody
fields.text: This, too, would be a good song...

fields.name: an anonymous contributor
fields.text: You sure do hate a lot of things.  Is there anything you love?

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: I read the newspaper today, and there was a short blurb about the Oscars, so I know it was Crash.  I made it longer than the Superbowl.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: I forgot to put the inspiration for this post.  Some of these strips appeared on the Something Awful forums, and Neal showed them to me.  I thought they were so great that I wanted to show the world.  I made some of the ones on this page, and some of the SA forum goons made the others.

fields.name: A perfect stranger
fields.text: So I saw the link for this on a friend's blog and this is by far one of the funniest things I've seen in a long time. I don't Garfield has ever made me laugh out loud until today. This is going under my favorites for whenever I need to laugh til I pee myself.

fields.name: Andrew Monkey
fields.text: Crap...  At 2:31 AM on march 17th, I just found out crash won.  Thanks Shauvon, thanks a lot.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: If I have to know, everyone does!  I'll take you all down with me.

fields.name: Peter
fields.text: Natalie's short hair makes her hotter.

fields.name: Aili
fields.text: Welcome to Spring. . . AT THE END OF THE WORLD!!!!!!!!!!Just kidding.  We got somewhere between 3 and 5 inches here! It IS kind of amazing.

fields.name: realname
fields.text: Looks like a really bad comb-over.

fields.name: Nikkie
fields.text: I LOVE FUNKY/COOL/PUNK HAIR!!!I have some killer products that could spike your hair in no time if you are interested!!Well done.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: I am really interested in some spiking products.  This can of hair spray and I are currently not on speaking terms.

fields.name: Your Mom
fields.text: There's a difference between denying conformity and wreaking random havoc.  Tossing acid on the Mona Lisa doesn't provide an alternative to conformity--it just destroys something special and rare.  As far as I'm concerned, denying conformity has more to do with developing and living by an independent set of principles regardless of their populariy rather than mindlessly refusing to do some things just because other people are doing them.  There are plenty of people who mindlessly reject the mainstream lifestyle, especially in their physical appearance, but conforming with non-conformists sounds suspiciously like conformity to me.  Besides--how the hell do you expect get a summer job now?

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: I agree that pouring acid on the Mona Lisa would be a terrible thing to do.  The Mona Lisa would not grow back in a matter of weeks.

fields.name: an anonymous contributor
fields.text: your mom is right, mom's are nearly always right.  listen to her. this page has turned into a shauvon journal about your life and your angst.  get livejournal for that, i believe that it would be much more useful for you to provide observations about life (in general), advice, and perhaps even a few entertaining stories.  go back and read some of your previous entries, the ones about actually denying conformity.    i know you are capable, i have seen it in the past, and when you do try to discuss real issues you tend to do it very well.

fields.name: Peter
fields.text: I disagree, Shauvon's mom is wrong. There are plenty of places  that will hire you if you have a silly hair cut. I had a job with a big red mohawk earlier this year. Your son could be doing drugs, drinking, or just being a general asshole. Instead he's a super nice and smart guy, and the only freshman I know who I can hold a decent conversation with that doesn't devolve into some ridiculous recounting of how much bicardi he drank at kappa-alpha-kappa-beta-fracka-tacka-macka-lacka over the weekend.Your comparison to throwing acid on the mona lisa is just plain silly. Shavon isn't doing anything disrespectful or destructive, he's getting a cool haircut. You might not think it's cool, but that's why your name is 'mom'. =)Self expression takes many forms, this is one of them. Shauvon isn't 'conforming to non-conformists', he's just getting a haircut that he likes. And he's doing that knowing that his own mother, along with many others, are going to dish out a lot of criticism because of how different from everybody else he looks. Doesn't he get it? We're all supposed to look the same! Conform, Shauvon! Or else you won't be able to get a job and survive in this world!! AHHHH!You did a great job raising Shauvon, if I were you i'd pick your battles. This is a minor one.

fields.name: Mom Again
fields.text: Interesting post, Peter, but I hardly think I've 'picked my battle' on this one.  If I was gearing up for war, I'd be pulling the financial plug, threatening reprisals, and pushing Shauvon's emotional buttons.  Instead, I just made a few observations which he is free to accept or reject as he pleases.  My point was and is a general one, addressing the real definition of non-conformity.  (I agree with the post that urges more philosophical dialogue and less cringing angst.)  Here's the thing:  Shauvon has always insisted he hates having everyone make comments about his height, claiming that it makes him feel self-concious and freaky.  Then he turns around and does something to modify his appearance which basically adds about five more feet to his height--in other words, he now stands out more than ever.  I think, at the very least, he's forfeited the right to complain about people gawking or making comments about his appearance.  And while it's true that this new look is hardly a permanent alteration and Shauvon's appearance is, of course, his to do with what he likes, as someone who cares about him, I have to question whether there isn't some sort of self-destructive mechanism at work here.  He doesn't like being treated like a freak, so he makes himself more freakish.  Hmmmmm.  Of course, it's hard for me to relate to anyone who spends lots of time fussing over how they look, whether they're trying to look like a movie star or a freak.  Outward appearance is only a manifestation, and I think most people would be happier with themselves if they spent more time working on what's inside and less time primping in front of a mirror.  But that's just my opinion.  Oh, and my name isn't really Mom.  That, too, is only a manifestation.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
You're right, this is only a manifestation.  That's why it barely matters at all.  This is a message to the world.  I am telling the world that nothing can stop me.  I do get annoyed when people talk about how tall I am, but there is absolutely nothing I can do about it except embrace it and get used to it.  This is a message to myself.  There is absolutely no way that I can get out of the 'freak pool.'  However, there is no reason to stay on the boring shallow side.  I might as well dive in and have some fun.



The world is spinning out of control.  It seems like everyone around me is abusing some sort of substance.  I've eaten alone almost every day because the idiots here seem to hate me now (after I took on the 'mom' manifestation and just tried to help them).  I haven't slept very well in about five weeks.  I am forced to miss Crazy Monkey shows because I have to go to Winter's Tale practice, which involves sitting in a hallway alone for four hours waiting to appear on stage for three minutes to say  two lines.  My camera does not work at all, so although I spent $350 over the summer to be able to take pictures of things, I can't.  I am completely self conscious about my body.  I have so many neuroses about food that it  sometimes makes me nauseous just to look at it.  Society has crumbled into this terrifying, money-obsessed, conservative, creativity crushing monster, and there is no way to escape the fact that I will have to become part of it some day.  People constantly point out traits about me that I have absolutely no control over.



Everything around me is out of my control, so it is important for me to be able to know that I am in control of something.  I can look in a mirror and say, I'm not putting up with this anymore.  I don't have to put up with it anymore.  I never did, nobody ever does.  It sounds ridiculous, but it gives me hope in the future.  If I can cut my hair and completely change the way I look, maybe all of those other things can change, too.  Even if that means just accepting things.



If you find yourself offended or concerned or otherwise effected by something as trivial as a haircut, maybe you need to look at dealing with some of your own concerns about control.  Everyone needs to accept that there are things outside their grasp.



One more thing.  Peter, I'm a sophomore.

fields.name: Andrew
fields.text: Is shauvon denying conformity or conforming to non-conformity? That's probably a question only Shauvon really knows the answer to, but I'm pretty sure when you consciously decide to deny conformity, it sorta defeats the point. One should be more focused on being his or herself and the word 'conformity' should never even enter the picture. So basically what I'm getting at is that this is A) a sweet haircut B) something that everyone is reading wayyyyyyyy too much into and C) probably the least big deal of things that someone could do to their body. He didn't get a tatoo or a piercing. He cut some hair, which will majestically rise once again like a phoenix from the ashes in a matter of a few weeks. No harm done! And some jobs see haircuts like that as a benefit. Just not the soul-sucking, mindless, corporate-driven ones, which, unfortunately, are usually the best-paying. I'm just saying that there are options. And Shauvon, we usually eat dinner at around 5 every day. IM me if you'd ever care to join. We are very accepting of all creeds, colors, religions, beliefs, and haircuts. Especially tri-hawks.

fields.name: Peter
fields.text: To Shauvon's mother, Well put. But on one hand you're saying that it is simply an outward appearance which is not as important as the inner self. This is all true. But then you say that this concerns you because it might be indictative of some deeper inner conflict in Shauvon. So then this isn't *just* a physical appearance thing anymore. Assigning psychological quirks or strengths to one's clothing or haircut is an almost purely subjective and arbitrary practice. While you may be concerned that a certain haircut might be signs of inner pain, I might think that a certain haircut is a sign of newfound inner strength and independence. It's a useless practice to get into.As far as the definition of denying conformity goes, there are many many ways one can deny conformity. There is the type of conformity denial you speak of, the inner one where one sticks to one's beliefs in the face of adversity. This is probably the best and most valuable kind, but it is not the *only* kind. There is also the physical conformities. People dress a certain way to fit it, some young girls won't eat in order to conform to an ideal body type, there is a standard outward appearance that people conform too which Shauvon has choosen to deny. Voila! Conformity, consider yourself denied!Saying your name is 'mom' was a joke, I hope you don't think I was being disresctful, that is really really not how I meant to come off as. Every post I've read from you is very intelligent and articulate, so I object with a great deal of respect.Shauvon, if you're a sophmore, then how come I just met you this year? MMMMMMMM?!?!?!?! Trickster! Just kidding. Won't make that mistake again, sorry.

fields.name: Andrew Monkey
fields.text: Ok, every body wanna know why Shauvon got the trihawk?  He did it because he wanted to, not to meet any one's expectations and despite any weird looks he might get.  To me, that spells about the first half of denying conformity.  As for it making him stand out more, it is something different for people to identify him, apart from 'mile high Shauvon,' and we all know that has nothing to do with his mid flight activities.Also, I am a huge proponent of doing ridiculous things with what you have, while you still have them.  Hair is something that not all men are going to be able to keep, and you can't always predict if you're going to lose it!  Luckily, it continues to replace itself, but only for a limited time!Gentlemen, I implore you: DO SOMETHING STRANGE WITH YOUR HAIR!  Just not the trihawk, you don't have the rights to that.

fields.name: your mom
fields.text: When we moved to Ohio in 1983, Indiana was on the same time as Ohio, but when we moved back to Indiana in 1987, we had to move our clocks ahead an hour.  I've always thought of that as the hour I'll never get back.  Come to think of it, I guess that lost hour was just like all the other hours of my life. I'll never get any of them back.  So I guess the years I've spent being bitter over that lost hour were a real waste of time.  Oh well. At least I've realized the error of my ways before it's too late.  You should stop mean-mouthing time.  It's all there is.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: They should at least be kind to the working man.  They should have the lost hour at 2 in the afternoon, instead of 2 in the morning.  That way we're not losing an hour of sleep, but we're losing an hour of work.  Wouldn't that be nice?

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: Come on, people.  That happens once every HUNDRED YEARS!  This is a special thing, here.  It's too bad we missed 1/2/03 4:05:06, though, because it's in standard timestamp format.

fields.name: Adam
fields.text: Just to let you know Shauvon, I believe that you people in Indiana and Ohio are now on the same time now. I might be wrong however.Since I'm in MN, I all ready had to deal with the dreaded daylights savings time. However, I must admit that I do enjoy having light until 7:45 PM right now. Just kinda annoying dealing with it.

fields.name: Little Boy Blue
fields.text: Hehe I love that lil bit about teaching Liberal Arts at and Engineering School. I really think its true that short guys are intimidated by you. I mean seriously, he could have just said 'No, this is last minute you need to take it' and not take you outside and yell so the other students could hear it. I mean, someone in my lab got yelled at the other day but that was cuz he posted data as his own that he got from somebody else. See he did something wrong so he deserved to get yelled at, but just asking late to not take an exam isn't a reason to be yelled at. I think you should just walk on your  knees so short teachers don't yell at you all the time.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: Nah, I find it cute and endeering.  I also find it amazing that someone posted a comment before I was even finished uploading the post.

fields.name: your mom
fields.text: I'm so proud of you.  Because of your phenomenal size, it is critically important that you be a man who can exert self-control. All animals, especially male animals, have an instinctive drive to attack the biggest member of the herd or pack.  I fear you will be challenged again and again and again by people who see you as the embodiment of everything wrong in their own lives.  Clearly there would have been no point in arguing with the lil' fella--people who are utterly convinced of their own correctness rarely listen to alternative points of view.  And, as you know, I do not believe yelling is ever an appropriate form of reasoned discourse.  After all, if you have to yell at me to get my attention, then you ain't sayin' nothin' I wanna hear.  Anyone who resorts to yelling is already out of control, so you were wise to back away slowly, the same way you would get away from a snarling, snapping dog.  I'm glad you took the test to get it over with and I'm even more glad you refused to take the teacher's hissy-fit personally. You proved that you are, indeed, the bigger man.

fields.name: big fan
fields.text: Break a leg or two, dude.

fields.name: somebody
fields.text: Shauvon,I've checked onto this website every few weeks since ROAD because I find it to be, well, really fascinating and fun to read. I wanted to say this to you because I think you have a great chance to make a definite success in the theatre department in the future. I hope that someday you can be excited about an opening night even if your only in 10 seconds of a play. It's sometimes disconcerting to read that you feel like the role you received was not up to what you think you deserve. Instead of focusing on the size of your role, you could see how lucky you were that you were cast in Jeff's last show at Purdue. Some seniors, who have spent four years studying theatre here have never gotten the chance to work with him and would trade places with you in a split second. This isn't at all supposed come across as a negative view of your focus or work on the show. I think you are doing a great job and your stage presence is wonderful. I just hope you see what you have been given, or if that doesn't work, see what others have not been given. Anyways, from my experience, itâ€™s the grateful and humble that get far in the department. Others (especially designers) pay more attention to those who truly do their work for the art and not for the 15 (or 10) minutes of fame. I guess all I am saying is, I hope you love this, all of this as much as some of us do. Itâ€™s the challenging, complicated and sometimes unpleasant work which makes the performance process truly exciting, at least in my opinion. And thatâ€™s just my opinion, so take it or leave it. But thatâ€™s all.Break all the legs in the house during Winterâ€™s Tale. :)Caitlin Mick

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: I just want to make it clear that I'm not disappointed in my part for the Tale.  I'm so extremely proud to be a part of this production, and I really feel so honored to be able to work with such talented individuals.  I'm just trying to cope with being such a spectacle.  I'm pretty uncomfortable with myself, so I'm slowly working on getting over that.

fields.name: some weirdo
fields.text: I wish you would show at least a little bit of compassion for the feeble-minded.  After all, poor Joey has to live with himself 24 hours a day, and that's surely enough of a karmic payback for anybody.And I also hope you can find some way to have at least a little bit of fun yourself this weekend.  You might have a lot more fun if you could lighten up a little and let the idiots be the way God made them...

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
way to deny conformity by sticking up for the system. we're all very proud of you.

point the second: there is nobody in this world that has less of a right to mock somebody else's haircut than you.

I'm constantly impressed by your need to mock and belittle others despite how much you claim to hate it when people do it to you. At least these people that you label as 'drags on society' don't spend the better part of their free time insulting the behavior of others.

hope you don't leave your hypocritical self off of that list.

also, it's spelled 'ridiculous'. For the amount that you use it you should probably be able to spell it correctly.

fields.name: M.S.
fields.text: Sounds like someone took the 'idiot' label a bit too personally.   I don't think Shauvon was necessarily talking about you, Cameron, but I can see why you might've thought he was.  After all, you're spending your free time insulting the way he spends his free time insulting others, which makes his little hypocrisy seem amateurish.  Also, before you belittle someone else's spelling, you should probably learn how to punctuate.  Better yet, let's all work on ourselves a bit more before we start telling other people how to be.  That's why I don't want to tell you who I am--because I KNOW I'm an idiot and I don't need any other idiots to point that out for me.  Let he who is without idiocy cast the first stone...

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
The difference, my friend, is that I spent about 2 minutes insulting something that Shauvon has recently made into a pastime. I was not personally offended by anything that he said in this post. I did not think that the label 'idiot' was pointed at me, though it has been in the past. I am getting tired of Shauvon spouting off crap about how he hates it when people are cruel and judgmental when basically all he does is rip on people for doing what they want to do and trying to be happy. I understand that he's not happy, but it's nobody's fault but his own and constantly blaming his unhappiness on the random actions of drunken frat boys is getting a little old. It's also not very healthy.

You don't need to be personally insulted by the words of another to feel justified in attacking their hypocrisy. This argument is a matter of principle because I'm getting really tired of the anti-social poser that Shauvon has become. I'm not going to keep reading this thread because, unlike you people, I have better things to do with my time. Feel free to continue arguing with me, but I've said my piece and I wash my hands of it completely.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
Antisocial is an interesting term.  Poser is an interesting term.  The fact that supporting our police force in what must be a terrible job is met with such negativity is interesting.



My website is completely independant, so I can therefore say absolutely anything I want to.  The Purdue Exponent is a school-supported publication, so I thought they should have a little more interest in not supporting illegal activity on campus.  I also thought that using terms like 'poop' and 'crap-ton' was a tad unprofessional for a published newspaper.



The fact of the matter is that this man should be singled out and ridiculed for this article, and the travesty that it is.  Instead, he's getting a degree.  He's getting a degree in professional and creative writing.  How does that make sense?

fields.name: GOD
fields.text: way to sidestep camerons issues

fields.name: Aili
fields.text: Cameron,I guess it's lucky for me that you've washed your hands of this 'argument' because I dare say you wouldn't much appreciate my interjections if you hadn't already 'washed your hands' of the matter.  Perhaps one of the other brilliant theologians you drink with and who inexplicably follow the many threads of this website despite your venomous animosity towards my brother will take up your charge.I would like to make the following observations:I think you may have mistaken 'antisocial' for sober.  I'm sure it's an easy mistake for you and your friends to make.  Maybe by the time you've gotten your degree and been to a few more frat parties, you'll understand such subtle nuances.I think you also may have mistaken 'arguing' for spouting off and shutting down.  Again, it can be tricky for those of us who aren't particularly interested in learning or growing or participating in social interplay to recognize the differences, but, please, benefit from my few extra years of experience - there are actually differences between thoughtful engagement with the wide world around you and braying like a jackass.And perhaps - and this is just a suggestion, here - no need to take it personally - you might want to also check a dictionary and a mirror to bolster your understanding of the terms 'hypocrite,' 'ridiculous' (however you choose to spell it), and 'anti-social.'  Oh, and I'd be willing to bet that your haricut might not pass muster on any number of makeover shows you might currently be watching on Lifetime on Shauvon's television.Just some friendly observations - I hope you're enjoying all of those many things you have to do with your time.  I look forward to reading and learning from the wisdom of your future musings on the way things should be.

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
Let me just talk a moment and disprove about 90% of the bullshit you just spouted:

-I've never been to a frat party

 /-I could count on one hand the number of times that I've been drunk since Christmas

 /-I don't watch Lifetime

 /-If Shauvon wants his TV then he can say something to us instead of being 'anti-social' and 'passive aggressive'

 /

We've never excluded Shauvon from any of our activities, drunk or sober. He's been shutting us out for months: behavior that I and my 'drunk' friends consider 'anti-social.' You can believe what you want about us and you can be so ridiculously naive as to think that Shauvon is the perpetual victim in our sadistic games, but you're not here, so you have no idea what's been going on or what is currently going on. All you are getting is one side of the argument consistently delivered by the sniveling drama queen.

By the way Shauvon, it's impressive that you can actually, with a straight face, mock somebody else's major after dropping out of one of the easiest departments at this school because it was too much work for you.

And Aili, if my life ever becomes so sad that I'm taking personal or career advice from a mid-20's waitress at a comedy club then I will have reached and surpassed the point at which your limited life experience will be able to help me. I don't know why every argument you make has to come down to alcoholism, but as I understand it Shauvon's new theatre friends drink as much if not more than we do. I think your issues with alcohol are much more significant than any of our's are.

My point in this entire argument though is not to aim cheap shots at the people that choose to argue with me. My point is to question Shauvon's right to belittle others. He has spent a lot of time while I've known him talking about how people shouldn't be stupid and asinine. He's spent even more time talking about how much he hates it when people insult and belittle him. What does i

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
t say to you that most of the posts on this site are centered around insulting others and questioning their contribution to society? Maybe if Shauvon wasn't so ridiculously insecure he'd be able to live by his own supposed ideals. I think I understand the meaning of 'hypocrisy' just fine. Perhaps you are the one that needs a lesson in definitions.

One more small point Shauvon, you can't be a non-conformist and then spout off repeatedly about how stupid people are when they think that particular laws are unfair and stupid. You know what's interesting? America is the only country with significant problems with alcoholism and drunk driving. You want to know why? Of course you don't, but I'm going to tell you anyway. Because of the sheltered and puritan way that people are brought up in this country alcohol is hailed as taboo for anybody who is under 21. Apparently once you reach that age you are entirely responsible and are thus no longer at fault if you choose to engage in consumption of alcohol. In France, where kids start drinking with their parents at a young age there is virtually no drunk driving and basically no alcoholism because drinking isn't a big deal to them. It's people like you that make drinking such a problem in this country. Yes, we engage in the occasional drink because we enjoy it. We don't do it to a self-destructive level nor do we do it very often. As I've said, I'm averaging less than once a month right now so I don't know how you could even possibly think that I have a problem. I think it's absolutely ludicrous that the drinking age in this country is 21. We can go to war for our country at 18, but we can't have alcohol? It's stupid. I understand that underage drinking is illegal, but I don't really care. If I get caught then I will accept the consequences of my behavior, but the threat of being caught is not enough to detour me from engaging in activities that I enjoy that are not illegal for any good reason. Unlike you, I don't blindly

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text: follow laws that I disagree with just because you say that I should.

fields.name: somebody
fields.text:
'The Purdue Exponent is a school-supported publication'

No it isn't.  It gets no funding from the university and thus is completely independent.

fields.name: Aili
fields.text: Hee hee. This is fun! I'm gald to see you're doing so much with the time you don't have to argue with me. I'm also glad to see that you calmly think through your arguments, and that you never level cheap shots at the people you're arguing with. What? Jump to short-sighted conclusions about a person you've met once or twice? Oh, not the Great and Powerful Cameron - no, never! I REALLY like how you're able to read between the lines and find meaning to things that I never knew I put there - it's amazing. What breathtaking divinations will you come up with next?! You're truly a sage. I mean, you must be - in just four posts, you've managed to sound like every other angry, disenfranchised, self-important, lonely, lost little white boy with an inflated sense of entitlement I've ever met. You can't possibly all be wrong, right? I, and all of the other bored net-surfers who wander across this site, have a lot to learn from you. And go ahead and have a drink tonight - you've earned it after all of this hard work! Your well reasoned bullet points have totally convinced me that you've earned the right to kill off as many braincells as you choose.  They are your braincells, afterall, & I firmly believe that everyone has the right to make their own choices about their bodies. Pshaw - addictive-schmaddictive. Thanks to you, I see now that all of those geneticists, psychologists, and chemists are totally wrong. And I can't WAIT until you move to France. Just imagine all of the insights you'll bring us across the annonymous leagues of cyberspace then! Be still, my heart! I'll bet you'll absolutely love it there, what with all the rioting and burning cars and hundreds of thousands of disenfranchised white boys with no jobs & lots of wine, and no unfair, nonsensical, discriminating laws at all. I can hardly wait, oh Sagacious one, for what deep and meaningful insights you'll impart next, between your highly pressing social & professional engagements, of course. Please, teach me more!

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
Gee, it's impressive that you knock me for making ridiculous generalities about people I've only met a few times when the basis of your argument is that I and my friends are all alcoholics even though you've never seen a single one of us with a drink.

Apparently I have plenty to learn from you about asinine sarcasm, which is special considering how much I've been hailed as the sarcastic jack ass of my cliche.

Just so you know though, a little education would be helpful if you plan on actually have an argument with anybody. Facts, rather than ill-stated opinion, heresay, and propoganda tend to work best in an argument.

That said here are some facts for you: the vast majority of doctors actually recommend having a drink or two every day as it lowers blood pressure and decreases your risk for heart disease. Also, most doctors and nearly all psychologists agree that alcoholism is not a chemical dependency; it is, in fact, a means of self-gratification meant to mask other emotional issues. Consequently, no geneticists that I've ever heard of has claimed that alcoholism is an inherited disease because it stems from lack of self-esteem and not anything physical or chemical.

Now that I've said all that I'm sure you're going to say something about how I have low self-esteem and that I just proved your argument, but all you'll succeed in doing is proving my theory that you just sit down at your computer and pour out a bunch of crap without actually responding to any of my talking points. As I've said many times before I am not an alcoholic by any description of the word, nor am I nearly the 'angry, disenfranchised, self-important, lonely, lost little white boy' that your brother is. I'm genuinely curious to see how long you can go in this argument without saying anything interesting or original without pointlessly repeating yourself to no logical end.

fields.name: Mike
fields.text:
Alli- 'I firmly believe that everyone has the right to make their own choices about their bodies'

Then what else is there to say on the matter?  We aren't you nor do I think anyone here cares how perfect you and your one-sided opinions are.



People live their own lives and thats what makes life worth living.

fields.name: GOD
fields.text:
Alli what the FUCK did you say.  We the members of the sane community can not understand your words.  I wonder if I could understand your quote if my brain were as unbalance as yours. 

For your information by the time your brothers moves out of your or your parentsâ€™ house I will most likely have earned my PhD.

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
Oh my god, that was probably the most hilarious thing I've ever read. Thank you for arguing my points by saying that I'm gay. You've really taught me something valuable about arguing: when somebody doesn't have something legitimate to say chances are they will just question your sexuality in an effort to unnerve you and then disappear into the unimaginably huge black hole that is the internet.

Not that I really care what you think, but I'm not gay and have had a wealth of relationship and sexual experience. I don't where I indicated that I was stressed in anyway. I have two projects to finish and my year is done, most of my finals don't even matter. You must be stressed about being such a miserable failure just in general, but I, being the good person that I am, wouldn't call attention to the fact that you've done nothing productive with the 'education' that you received.

Ok, your first article: the most recent study referenced is 8 years old and the entire thing talks about ethanol, which is only a component of some types of alcoholic beverages. Beer, for instance, doesn't contain ethanol. Also, your article proves pretty conclusively that there are no firm findings to support either of our claims, but I guess if you can't prove your own point you might as well nullify both of our's. That article is also from a site that openly supports the '12 step' program which has been conclusively proven to be completely useless (they have an impressive %5 success rate). Basically you should probably check the validity of your sources. I could go on the internet and find a 'paper' by a 'doctor' that says just about anything I want it to... or I could write my own.

The second article was written by writers at a nonprofit organization for 'interests in brain science, immunology, and arts education' whatever that means. All they did in that article is regurgitate ideas that a few neurobiologists had. Even with this seemingly reputable source they still didn't

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
manage to say anything conclusive, but presented a number of conflicting views.

The third article comes from a 'substance-free' international fraternity. It's interesting that you should cite a fraternity since you and your brother have spent a significant amount of time insulting there very people. That said, a letter from an alumni of a puritanical organization is not exactly cold, hard fact.

That said, if you have any reputable sources that you'd like to share feel free to do so because I am genuinely interested in where you get your bullshit information. Let's see how far I can push your confirmation bias:

 [This article, which cites a study done by Lancet Medical Journal four years ago, says that moderate daily consumption of alcohol is good for you](http://www.epic4health.com/algoodforyou.html) 

The National Institute for Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism even says that moderate alcohol consumption is beneficial to you.

All of the problems you're discussing stem from binge drinking regularly. If that point isn't clear to you: the problems you've pointed out are only applicable to those who drink more than 5 drinks in one session several times a week. I know one person that does this and I don't associate with him.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have work to do as I am in school working toward providing myself with a respectable future.

fields.name: Chris
fields.text:

Nanomolecular Undergrad Research

Physics Minor

Astro-Physics Minor

Mechanical Engineering Minor

Three Semester participation in Purdueâ€™s Engineering Projects in Community (EPICS)

I donâ€™t think I should leave out the fact many of my major specific courses meet concurrently graduate level courses.

fields.name: Aili
fields.text: Thanks, Cameron.I'm glad that we've come to an amicable agreement about something. It is hilarious. And it's nice to hear that I can pique your curiosity. How much time, exactly, did you spend reading through the articles I quoted? I'm glad I can be a conduit of enlightenment for you. Oh, and I take back the thing about being gay. You've demonstrated beyond a shadow of a doubt that you're not interested in boys at all. Way to demonstrate Soctratic rhetoric! Oh, and I'm glad you've got your friends (including, apparently, GOD - although I'm not quite sure whose GOD, exactly - I doubt any of the Hindu gods would use the term 'FUCK') involved with our rousing discussion.  I'm sure they'll enjoy the rush one gets from carefully crafted intellectual argument. They seem like men of discerning taste and verbal prowess. And, just so that we understand each other, I am so proud to be associated with you and your long list of conjectured accomplishments, even just through the vague annonymity of the Internet.  Think what my grandchildren will say when I can tell them 'I argued with him when . . . he was just a good person without an STD.'

fields.name: Cameron
fields.text:
You know, some day you might actually have something worthwhile to say and everybody will probably think you're being sarcastic. Just a friendly warning, you might want to say something sincere before you lose the ability to do so.

I also don't know where you go from me being gay to me having an STD, but clearly if you're the one with grandchildren then you are the one who's been having unprotected sex and have a much greater chance of having an STD.

Remind me to ask you, when and if that day comes, 'who's the unwitting human who's essence you've stolen?'

fields.text: I'm glad that I have friends that have at least a 'conjectured' list of accomplishments.

fields.name: Mike
fields.text: Aili, please stop talking as you will only embarrass yourself further.  You have clearly demonstrated your lack of maturity by calling someone gay in an attempt to draw attention away from your own flawed logic.  I hardly call that an 'intelligent' conversation and think that everyone, including Shauvon, would wholeheartedly agree.

If you ever get to the point where you can look at yourselves honestly and understand just how delusional you are, please be aware that you can always receive psychological counseling as part of your PUSH benefits.  Make an appointment at http://www.purdue.edu/CAPS/

fields.name: Mike
fields.text:
I don't believe this was a laughing matter.  If you have something to say it would be best to actually address the topic at hand rather than avoid our points entirely.

Instead, you reply with something no better than a five year-old telling a 'your mom' joke...taking low blows any chance you get by stating we need counseling, referring to us as 'boys' or not 'real adults' (which as far as I'm concerned is 18 by law in the state of Indiana) in a feeble attempt to make youself look like you've actually said something important.  That is hardly what I would call an adult-like characteristic.

I still fail to realize the whole point of your argument, or was there one?

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
Well, this sure was quite a read.  I don't know what to say, honestly.  I guess I'll just point out some facts, just so nobody thinks that I'm attacking them again (although I'm completely sure someone will think I am).  Aili is currently attending Graduate School at IUPUI.  She also works at Connor Prairie, where she has quite a bit of power.  I really never meant this to be an attack of anyone (except Joey Marburger, because he was asking for it).  I have spent the last several weeks working with thirty or so of my dearest friends in a completely alcohol free environment, entertaining hundreds of people.  I hope the fact that I used the word alcohol in that sentence doesn't cause anyone to think that I am making a judgement about your lifestyle and choice of pasttime.  I understand that I haven't been around here very much.  Barry (my other roomate) hasn't been around at all, either.  I am going to avoid saying anything about Chris' comment, short of mentioning that he still thinks that it is appropriate to post on my website, even though he refuses to aknowledge my existance.  I am extremely honored that God has commented on my website, but I don't know why he is interested in pursuing a PhD.  I always thought God would be much more coherent than that.



Obviously, this is the way that I am going to continue to manage my website.  If I can get this ammount of response and argument to ensue after every post, I will be extremely satisfied.  It's not like it's very hard to provoke you people.

fields.name: Your Mom
fields.text: Good grief!  I try to monitor this site every day, and for several weeks I have seen very little action.  Then I take a weekend off, and BOOM!  All I have to say is Aili, I know you have better things to do than bait these guys; you guys need to keep in mind that the Internet is very public and you never know who is keeping tabs on you (including, apparently, school officials); and the tone of your original post, Shauvon, was fairly harsh and therefore opened the door to a good deal of hostility.  I know you like the idea of getting a lot of interaction going on your website, but I'm not sure I see the point in all this snarling and snapping.  I just wish you would all play nice.

fields.name: Andrew Monkey
fields.text: Weekly my ASS!!!

fields.name: Scott
fields.text: Wow ego is such a motivator I guess. As far as drinking goes, its all fun and games until you run someone over. I dont' care is someone drinks to get drunk. Just dont' do it behind a steering wheel. I also think that narcasism really comes into play on these comments. Do you really care about the issue? or  do you really care that you are right?Oh and I guarentee someone is gonna slam me for this comment.

fields.name: Mom Again
fields.text: It's funny that you should make this comment about ego, Scott, because I'm starting to think that ego is the root of all evil.  Whenever we get totally self-obesessed, we lose sight of so many other things.  I know ego is important for self-preservation, but mindless self-preservation seems to defeat the purpose of existence.  Life is so much larger than our momentary little experience of it, yet we fight and die for so many petty and trivial things.  Surely if there IS a point to living, it has to be larger and more important than our own precocious little egos.  In other words, I have to believe that having an ego is merely a means to an end, and by focusing on the means all the time, we completely lose sight of the end...

My goal for this list was to come up with a list of things people take for granted.  Sure, going to Italy or Paris would really be a highlight in someone's life, but it's the mundane things that make life.  That's why I've added two things to the list.  Number 103: Take a vacation in your own backyard, and Number 123: Watch someone skydive from the relative safety of the ground below them.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
I watched Live Free or Die Hard last night.  It was fantastic.  Let's take a look at my list, and see what made it, shall we?

'Yipee Kay Yay'  This token phrase made it in, of course.  I felt that used much better than the last two films, but it could never be as awesome as the first time.  This one was pretty obvious, so it's a bit of a freebie.a better ending than Die Hard with a Vengance  Live Free or Die Hard only got better and better as the movie went on, so the ending was the best part.  This was definitely a yes.John McClain has to fight a big German dude, who he ends up defeating using chains somehow. Lookout, though, because the German dude isn't actually dead.  This one wasn't perfect.  The bad guys weren't German, which was a disappointment.  John ends up fighting a small asian lady, which is just about the exact opposite of a big german dude.  However, it was extremely satisfying, and he did end up strangling her with elevator cables, which are pretty close to the chains he used in previous films.  Not perfect, but this one was fulfilled pretty well.McClain shows his technophobia.  Like most things from Die Hard 2, this seems to have never actually happened.  I'm content with going on like Die Hard 2 never happened.Bonnie Bodelia as Holly Gennero.  She never appeared, so IMDB was correct.  However, they did show a picture of her, and John's daughter played a major part, so the same 'familial' themes were held together.Reginald VelJohnson and Samuel L. Jackson both need to reprise their roles. They reall manned down on this one.  Neither of these guys were even mentioned, and it was a shame.  What is Reginald VelJohnson doing now anyway?The enemy better be a group of German mercenary terrorists who all use MP5's for some reason.  As I said before, the bad guys were not German.  They were an odd mixture of american computer hackers and French mercenaries, a choice I will never understand.  They did not use MP5's, but rather went with much more realistic modified UMP rifles, with a very well placed MP7 showing up, as well.  McClain finally ditched his Baretta for a much lighter, more modern composite handgun.  No Steyer Augs, but that MP7 was way cooler, anyway.John McClain wears a white tank top.  McClain wore some sort of tan shirt, which pretty much started at the same color his shirts usually end at.  He still ended with a satisfying ammount of blood on him, though, so they held true to the McClain look.  I don't have a problem with Bruce Willis being completely bald this time around.  Willis, and by extension McClain, is becomming a very old dude.Numerous Christmas references.  Again, they totally manned down.  The movie didn't have a single Christmas reference.'Winter Wonderland'  Granted, this was a stupid thing to wish for.  No matter how 'Die Hard' this song is, nobody in their right mind would have it during the credits of an Independance Day film.  Still, it would have been nice.

There you have it.  The results weren't too bad at all, and I really enjoyed the movie.  I was not expecting much, but they really delivered.  This was very much a Die Hard movie, and it truly deserves the name.



And for those of you waiting for a similar list for the Transformers movie, I'm afraid I'll have to disappoint.  I've made a lot of effort to learn everything I can about the movie, so I don't have a lot of unrealistic expectation.  Even still, my expectation is pretty high.

fields.name: Bralf
fields.text: I don't agree with bashing a movie solely based on its director either, but I do agree with bashing poorly-made movies for being poorly made movies.I'm not sure whether it was the constant attempts at inane humor (oh! A giant robot is PEEING on that bad guy! ROBOT PEE IS HILARIOUS!), the total misunderstanding about what the movie is about (the Autobots aren't really introduced until about an hour and a half into the movie, and even then they're just introduced; we never get to know them whatsoever. Also, the MAIN VILLAIN isn't formally introduced until the final half hour), the completely jumbled action sequences (I had no idea what the hell was going on in the final city battle), the gaping plotholes (what ever happened to the Mountain Dew-machine Transformer? Why in God's name do the parents not believe in Transformers when the Transformers completely annihilated most of the downtown area?!), or the extended parts that involved no Transformers and nothing to further advance the plot (anything involving Jon Voight and/or the 'hackers'), but I had a lot of ill-will in me after seeing Transformers.Luckily, the giant robots looked pretty awesome. And Shia LaBeouf was likable. Bumblebee was annoying and I can't imagine that anyone in the universe actually felt bad during his dramatic 'torture' sequence.And while I don't blame Bay's past failures or successes on this film, I do have to blame Bay for making a crappy movie this time around. Personally, I love Bad Boys II. I know how sad that sounds.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
Indeed, the film had some very serious problems.  Perhaps it was a bad decision for Steven Spielberg to pitch the film as being about 'a boy and his car,' instead of about 'Transformers.'  Perhaps it was a bad omen when one of the early versions of the screenplay had the Transformers not speaking at all.  Indeed, the film had some serious problems.



However, this review is not of the film.  No, this is a review of the review.  Indeed, the film was somewhat inadequate, but Jeffrey Westhoff's review of the film was disturbingly so.



That being said, all of Bralf's comments are valid.  Personally, I loved Michael Bay's The Island.  It isn't that sad to like a Michael Bay film, as long as it isn't Pearl Harbor

fields.name: A No-Sided Man
fields.text:
Well while we are talking about how people review movies. I really do not like it when someone sees something they don't like in a movie, then lets that feelings spill over into everything else in the movie. As humans, we do this all the time. I admit that sometimes I may not like the way a person wears their hair, so I assume I won't like them as a person at all. But you can't do this! For all I know that person is a rocket scientist or created the cell phone I'm using.



Back to Transformers, however, Yes the Autobots were not introduced until really far in. And yes alot of the movie didn't have to do with Transformers, but the human race. The producers had to make a movie that EVERYONE would like, not just the Transformer enthusiasts. And to do that they had to add other aspects. I thought the whole attack on the human race was a good touch. It made me feel more into the movie. (The only Transformers I ever watched was the Beast Wars series). And I also hated parts of the movie. Some of the scenes that were added could have been removed completley and would not have left and plot out.

 

But I feel, Braft, that your spilling your bad feelings for some scenes over into the other parts of the movie. There are plenty of other movies that in the action scenes you can't follow anything. But I like that. The chaos is what makes you feel like your there and in the movie. (Which I think Bay did a godo job of, he did lots of angles that were shot up at the robots rather than looking down)  And if nothing you have to be impressed by the sheer CGI of Transforming robots. I mean I'm sure that it was one guys job to animate Optimus primps left index fingers and nothing else!

 

Now I'm not saying you have to love the Movie Braft. Take a second, though, and remove the parts you didn't like of the movie and just watch the parts you liked. I bet you'll say wow that actually is an awesome movie.

It is by this deep and joyful curiosity that we may explain the fixed and animally ecstatic gaze of a child confronted with something new, whatever it be, whether a face or a landscape, gilding, colours, shimmering stuffs, or the magic of physical beauty assisted by the cosmetic art.

fields.name: a contributor
fields.text: But our accumulation of these pockets of debris in all our cities and towns is not involuntary at all--when we chose the society we've made, we chose the debris as well. We don't like to admit that, and we don't like to be reminded of it by having our messy corners exposed, but ultimately there's no denying it. Perhaps if we kept our debris-field in mind, we might not not continue to choose our ultra-consumer lifestyle. For your next photography study, perhaps you should follow the contents of the dumpsters to the landfill.

Some people are just too busy to think about it or they might be so use to it that it becomes less and less important to them until it soon becomes nothing.

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text:
Maybe it is that entire attitude which causes the problem in the first place. Everyone thinks that the filth is too systemic, that too many other people are doing the same thing, and so they feel no reason to do anything about it. All of these drunk college kids think the garbage is 'an SEP (Somebody Else's Problem) and so they see nothing wrong with leaving empty bottles and other garbage wherever they feel like. Bar owners aren't concerned with the runoff from their dumpster flowing right into an outdoor dining area or porch.

It isn't an SEP. It's everybody's problem (EP), and you can't just refuse to deal with it because you don't think anybody else will. It's very easy to say, 'well, nobody else is going to do anything about their filth, so who cares if I don't, either.' It's also pretty easy to empty and clean out cups and bottles before you throw them away, crush empty boxes to save space, try to dispose of nasty organic matter in alternate ways, and not just leave a bag of trash in the stairwell of your apartment building for weeks at a time. Sure, one small person may not make a difference, but you could at least have a very legitimate reason to feel superior to other people, which could certainly go a long way.

*Refuse the refuse*?

But I'm afraid you took what I said the wrong way. I don't think it's someone else's problem. Nore do I think it's too hard to clean a cup before throwing it away or save space by folding boxes. It's just seeing those dirty alleys made me a tad upset, and when I get upset, things I say tend to come out wrong.


I just don't want you, or anyone else for that madder, to think that I'm one of the bag guys who thinks negative about everything. It's not what I really think, and I regret posting that first comment in the first place. And anyway,I'm sorry for any confusion.

Oh, and I was walking by said alley last night, and I was getting ready to throw away an empty coffee cup I had just finished, and there was another cup full of liquid that someone had just left on the bench. I picked it up, and threw it out with my coffee cup into the trashcan sitting next to the bench.

fields.name: an anonymous contributor
fields.text:
To the 'fan' on Oct. 3--

I'm someone who many people have complained about being 'too negative,' but I'll never apologize for calling 'em like I see 'em, and neither should you. Sometimes it seems like we're all supposed to be divided into two camps: those 'realists' who are Mr. Grumpy Negatives or those Pollyannas whoclaim all is sweetness and light while the world is crumbling. 

But nothing is ever that black or white, of course. There are good things and bad things, and sometimes bad can be good and good can be bad. That's probably why these photos are so evocative--they compel us to reconsider those definitions. All that trash seems bad. But it is a result of our pleasant modern lifestyle, which is good. But such reckless disregard for the environment is bad. But the fact that someone noticed and we all want to do the 'right thing' is good. But what is 'the right thing'? And how do we do it? And what if we do the wrong thing by mistake? Worse yet, what if we do nothing? But who are we to *do* something? Aren't there smarter people out there than we are, and shouldn't we let *them* do what needs to be done? Besides, don't we all have plenty of other problems to take care of? I know I sure as hell do.

So you see, 'fan,' I don't think you should apologize for your posting. We're all in this together, and don't none of us know what's right or good or even worth mentioning.

Man, these pictures really make you think . . .

fields.name: this moron
fields.text: So much energy squandered trying to control things you can never possibly control! The screaming desperation, the raging fear . . . what good do they do you, really? Let me ask you something, dude. All those things you think are 'wrong' and 'negative'--what if they are exactly the way they're supposed to be? And what if you responded, not by struggling so frantically against them, but by trying to enjoy them in whatever way possible? What if you let go of the fear, what if you embraced the desperation,and what if you accepted your utter lack of ability to avoid thingsyou'd like to avoid? And what if you were told that the very answers you seek will be given to you--guaranteed--the moment you finally accept your lack of control? Could you do it? Could you let go of the blessed rage, embrace the ignorance, and maybe even start enjoying the chaos?

2.8 million is a lot, yeah, but hey, you could be living in downtown Mexico City, Sao Paulo, or Tokyo, with way more people, or New York City, with all kinds of density! You may think it's a dense, built up area around Southport and along Ashland but that's peanuts to Manhattan. And you can get food at any hour of the night, delivered to your doorstep.

fields.name: your mom
fields.text: Shopping for food seems to be quite an adventure in Chicago. I guess that's why I prefer to grow my own as much as possible. I'm exactly 0-tenths of a mile from the best tomatoes, green peppers, and zucchini in the world. And I can give you two bags full for free...

fields.name: your mom
fields.text: Listen to your mom.

fields.name: your mom
fields.text:
First of all, I want to say that the previous commenter was not me. I would not say 'listen to your mom,' because that would be the best way I can think of to make sure you would not listen to me. So, beware of imposters posing as your mother! (That's probably good advice for anyone.)

At any rate, I just recently defrosted my freezers and took the opportunity to inventory my food supplies. Since the data I derived dovetails nicely with your shopping trip, I thought you might be interested.

I currently have the following items I've grown and frozen:

60 pints peas; 102 pints green beans, 74 pints corn, 64 pints broccoli, 14 pints green peppers, 9 pints spinach, 20 quarts dried beans, 74 pints tomato sauce, 19 quarts tomato sauce, 30 pints soup, 24 quarts soup, 9 pints salsa, 1 quart salsa, 4 quarts tomato juice, 16 quarts grape and cherry juice, 3 quarts blueberries, 3 quarts strawberries, and 3 pints cranberries (the blueberries and cranberries are not from my garden, but I hope they soon will be). 

In addition, I anticipate harvesting at least 3 bushels of potatoes, 3 bushels of sweet potatoes, and multiple more pints of celery, sauce, soup, and salsa. (Knock on wood with the potatoes--anything can still happen!) Keep in mind, too, I net at least 3 dozen eggs a week for six months of the year, giving me 78 dozen eggs, about half of which I sell. I am also not counting the multiple bushels of lettuce we harvest each year (gotta be at least 10 bushels!) and the quantities of herbs, hot peppers, etc. 

While none of this is exactly cost-free because the seeds cost money and I've paid for tools, etc., and, of course, if you factor in my time the cost really goes up, but the point is that it costs nothing in terms of shipping or sales mark-up and it is as pure as food can be these days, being fertilized solely by poop from my chicken and goat friends. 

Now, I'm not suggesting everyone should grow all their own food, but I do think that anyone who can grow ANYTHING, should do so whenever possible. After all, the element we haven't even factored into the cost/benefit analysis is the karmic cost of buying crap at the store. I have to believe that when you kill a life form with your own two hands and immediately consume it, you are racking up much less of a karmic debt than you do when you allow someone else to do your killing for you. I am confident that because I know my tomatoes are going to turn into me, I take greater care of them while they are alive and I slaughter them with greater respect than any commercial grower can muster. 

Of course, that line of thinking goes way off in a completely different direction than a simple shopping trip . . .
