fields.name: Walt Whitman
fields.text:
Trippers and askers surround me.

People I meet, the effect upon me of my early life or the ward and city I live in, or the nation.

The latest dates, discoveries, inventions, societies, authors old and new,

My dinner dress, associates, looks, compliments, dues,

The real or fancied indifference of some man or woman I love,

The sickness of one of my folks or of myself, or ill-doing or loss or lack of money, or depressions or exaltations, 

Battles, the horrors of fratricidal war, the fever of doubtful news, the fitful events,

These come to me days and nights and go from me again,

But they are not the Me myself.

Apart from the pulling and hauling stands what I am,

Stands amused, complacent, compassionating, idle, unitary,

Looks down, is erect, or bends an arm on an impalpable certain rest, 

Looking with side-curved head curious what will come next,

Both in and out of the game and watching and wondering at it.

Backward I see in my own days where I sweated through fog with linguists and contenders,

I have no mockings or arguments, I witness and wait.

I really had the exact response. Everyone kept gushing about how good it was and I really wanted to like it but when anything gets that popular I can't help but assume it must be dumbed down enough to where I can't appreciate it. And story wise, there isn't anything revolutionary going on. But I agree with what you said about Cameron using cliches. He used them because it makes the story simple and will appeal to the widest audience possible. He did revolutionary things with visual effects, absolutely, but chose to keep the story as simple as a childrens' movie. And that's totally okay. I think you can have a great movie with simple effects and a complex story or complex effects and a simple story.

But I would only call a movie a masterpiece if it did both.

fields.name: Tyler
fields.text: Correction: I had the exact opposite response.*

fields.name: Shauvon
fields.text: I think our disparity is really just our definition of the word 'masterpiece.' I'm simply calling Avatar the ultimate work of James Cameron's career. I'm not saying it's a great film that deserves a place in history among other great films. I'm saying it deserves a place in history for being the object of so much passion and labor.

fields.name: Ryan
fields.text:
Inventing entire worlds, backstories, languages, etc. for a work of fiction is *nothing* new. Two concrete examples?

Tolkien invented multiple complete languages for Lord of the Rings.

Herbert invented an entire fictional bio-ecosystem for Dune.

And hundreds if not more of other fantasy and science fiction writers have done the same, to varying degrees.

fields.name: kber
fields.text: And, to keep the analogy going, I must point out that there always comes a moment of reckoning, fairly early on in any relationship, when you realize that this girl/job isn't as perfect as you'd thought. Blemishes appear, irritating things are said, annoying habits become increasingly unbearable, and mysterious odors take on a definitely unpleasant overtone. Be prepared for the day everything goes from rosy to black, and remember that that, too, will pass. Learn to ride both the highs and the lows, and sooner or later keeping your balance becomes second nature.

There's the problem, right there. You're (anonymously) commenting on my screenshot of someone else's repost of a picture of a web page featuring a random thought Andy Daly once had. He will most likely never see that comment, and I couldn't care less how funny you (anonymously) think he is, because he is someone who isn't Me.

This is the true futility of information in the information age.

fields.name: a complete nut
fields.text:
How facilely you dismiss the value of human discourse, even in this removed-to-the-fourth-degree format. Human history is nothing if not a desperate search for connection, and the internet, for all its many, many faults, does provide us with a new tool to explore the possibilities of mind meeting mind. Even if the connection is not real, the human brain registers it the same way it registers any intimate conversation. Information is not the point and never has been. I don't care what you know, what you think, or really anything else about you. I only care that you exist, and I can connect with you, however superficially, so that I know I'm not the only speck of dust drifting aimlessly through the enormous nothingness. The very futility you decry is, in fact, our common bond.

So there.

fields.name: your mom
fields.text:
Okay, so last night I was coming in from the goat pen, and as I was walking up the walkway to the porch, I saw Bartley lying in the grass there. As I walked by, he did not jump in front of me as he usually does, but rolled over and exposed his belly in a very alluring way, begging me to pet him. I thought, 'Oh, he's finally turning cute!' And I petted him on the head, and scratched his chin and . . . then I thought, 'Didn't you used to have more white fur?' I looked at him as I was petting him, while he was writhing around happily, and I was just SURE he used to have more white fur on his belly and his face. I looked at his face, and his eyes were the right color and his nose had that bump in it like it always has, so I thought, 'Wow, I must be getting Alzheimery. I really thought he had more white on him.' Then I turned around to go up the step AND THERE WAS BARTLEY!!!!! The cat I had been petting was someone else altogether, and Bartley was PISSED!

I ran to the door and yelled for Bob to come outside because something weird was going on. He came out and I showed him this new cat, who was a dead ringer for Bartley, except for the amount of white fur and the fact that the new guy still has all his original equipment. I was showing Bob how nice this new cat was by petting him when all of a sudden he attacked me, biting and scratching my arm, which put Bartley in motion, which put Not-Bartley in motion too. They both ended up in the driveway, rolling around like lions, howling and swishing their tails furiously. They ended up spending about ten minutes just howling at each other, during which time I'm pretty sure they were talking about me. I'm confident the new guy is Bartley's brother, who must live around the corner. He seemed very well-fed and well groomed, so I'm hoping I won't get rabies, but you never know. 

I haven't seen either Bartley or not-Bartley today, but I've had a raccoon raiding the bird-feeder all day, in spite of the fact that it's full-on daylight and 150 degrees.

It's always exciting around here . . .

fields.name: Ferp
fields.text: I grew up in a lower-middle class Puerto Rican/Dominican family and when I was a young chap, my parents used to ship me off to Puerto Rico for summer vacation all the time. I will say, Tang was a massive staple on the island and remember drinking it almost every night. I've had that flavor engrained in my DNA since I was 6 and now as a 36 year old man, I picked up a bottle of the Splenda stuff and it was god awful. Reading this article gives me hope and I think I will keep my eyes peeled on the imported stuff at 'my peoples' stores. This was quite the adventure, thanks for posting.
